Topic.Title: Samsung's S4 looks like S3.. with a lot of features that nobody will use.

Message.Msg: Overall I agree with that assessment. Thinner and lighter is good, a slightly larger display in the same physical length & width is a also positive, but the most promoted features such as eye tracking and gesture control is somewhat gimmicky. These type of features often sound cool but rarely work well in actual usage. Reminds me of the front facing camera and facial recognition to unlock a phone. It looked like it was going to be useful but then you discover it has problems in different lighting conditions and just isn't that reliable. After a while one just turns it off and goes back to a password or swipe. I like Samsung's build quality but this release doesn't advance the state of smartphones in any meaningful way.

Topic.Title: Intel releases Android Dual bootable on Windows 8

Message.Msg: I posted this yesterday but not too many people seem to gasped the significance of this. This news means ALL future PCs (especially PC hybrid) can run Android! So, for a PC hybrid, this means that in laptop mode, you can do your PC work in Windows and in tablet mode, you can run Android and be able to use all current Android apps! This will allow for new breed of products such as the Asus PadFone. There was also news yesterday from Google that Andy Rubin, head of Android has stepped down to be replaced by the head of Chrome OS. This sounds like Google plans to merge Chrome OS with Android. It won't be long before Apple merges their iOS with MacOS. Intel is in very good position here because it can support all 4 major OS's (Windows, MacOS, Chrome and Linux).

Message.Title: Why Apple will sign with Intel
Message.Msg: Devastating news out today that TSMC may only be at tape out stage for Apple's A7. This means Apple would not be able to have any new products with the A7 for this year's holiday shopping season if they stick with TSMC. There's only one way to salvage this situation and that is to sign with Intel who have already stated they will have their next-generation quad-core Atom SoC (“Bay Trail”) on 22nm available by this holiday season.

Message.Title: Microsoft Surface Pro sales hit 400K in a hurry
Message.Msg: Microsoft has sold 400,000 Surface Pros since launch, according to a Bloomberg report. That's not a bad start for a very pricey tablet -- starting at $899 -- considering that the Windows 8-based Pro launched only about a month ago. "That's a respectable number and it leads me to believe that Surface Pro will end up outselling Surface RT," Bob O'Donnell, an analyst at IDC, said in a phone interview. O'Donnell is referring to the RT version of Surface, which is less expensive, starting at $499, but it is not compatible with older Windows software. "It's something that we've predicated all along because of the compatibility that Surface Pro offers," he said. From Brooke Crothers

Topic.Title: Microsoft Surface Pro sales hit 400K in a hurry

Message.Msg: +The sales numbers have spoken. It looks like Microsoft has a veritable hit on their hands. With the intro of Haswell, some of the criticism around this PC will get addressed. Also, this leads the way for core series chips to be put to use in tablets which is probably a win for core series sales volumes. If I was Qualcomm or NVidia, I would be very scared about competition for tablet chips in this form which neither has a chance of competing with at least on the performance front. Windows 8 it seems is set to take off as a touch OS albeit a little slowly contrary to earlier reports.

Message.Title: Here's what I see happening with Apple, Intel and TSMC.
Message.Msg: Apple will fab their ARM chips for the Iphone 5 and Iphone 4 at TSMC's 28nm. Apple will use Intel Atom 22nm chips for their new Iphones. The Iphone 5 and Iphone 4's will be the low end, yesterdays product (Free with 2 yr contract). Apple still has to sell these, as they can't just stop selling ARM products the next day. The New Iphones and Ipads will have Intel chips and will be the high end Phones and Ipads. So Digitimes may be RIGHT in a way with Apples production split between Intel and TSMC. Apple may also not dump Samsung immediately, but will Phase them out over a year or so. Mark this Post. You heard it here first.

Topic.Title: Microsoft Surface Pro sales hit 400K in a hurry

Message.Msg: From the Cheat Sheet: The chip analyst JoAnne Feeney at Longbow Research reported that her conversations with vendors of components for personal computers imply to her that the second half is shaping up worse than expected, and might cause problems for PC-related names like Intel, Advanced Micro Devices, Nvidia, and Intersil Corporation (NASDAQ:ISIL). Feeney maintains Neutrals on all four names, commenting that “contacts now see desktop units down 5 to 10 percent for the year vs. our forecast for INTC DT segment to be down 4 percent year-over-year in 2013. Look for a slow Haswell ramp as last year’s inventory build, following a surprisingly weak second half, leads the industry to stick with the safer Ivy Bridge platform (socket compatible with Sandy Bridge, unlike Haswell) and for Haswell to make up less than 50 percent of desktop CPU shipments even in the fourth quarter.”

Topic.Title: Microsoft Surface Pro sales hit 400K in a hurry

Message.Msg: That makes sense and is not a surprise to me. Not only is socket 1155 compatible with Sandy Bridge but is is also compatible with Ivy Bridge 22nm. The Haswell socket 1150 supports the Haswell on chip VTR and will likely have most value when coupled with an OS that can take advantage of its power conservation features. Those are not exactly "desktop CPU" features. Power conservation will be an issue for laptop sysems. Socket 1155 motherboards are not only "safe" but they are very cheap since there are many suppliers. A neutral rating and a target price that yields a 5% dividend is pretty safe. That is how she selected the $18 target. $18 = 5%. If Intel declared a dividend incease when they declare next week, she will raise her target.

But Intel has woke up to this call, the future will be bright for Intel in this space as well as they will be bring same power and performance to even mobile phones. This game is not new to Intel. They were challenged like during notebook transition also. Google around for companies Transmeta etc., Where are they now? ARM will have the same future? The answer depends...I will leave it at that argument will take a couple of pages...

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: An overextended market always has a mean reversion. It may not be tomorrow but it won't be very far away. There is probably a lot of pressure on those who are underinvested but I would probably wait for a pullback to buy in. Also, while sticking with the uptrend, it is a good idea to get some hedges for the next one or two months as VIX (11.30) dropped to another multiyear low. The major indexes continue to move in the same pattern as they did in 2012 when the market topped in late March and then spent April and May in a correction.

Topic.Title: Samsung S4 is further proof that that A15 is a power hog

Message.Msg: Still no real good explanation why a smart phone needs a quadcore processor with a baby core. The Tegra 3 didn't do such a wonderful job on economizing the power. I suspect some consumers will leave certain apps running in the background that will keep all four cores running and draining the phone's power. They will complain about short battery life. I 'm anxious to see if all this power will be something consumers will appreciate and demand. I think Apple may be right about not making such a big deal about the processor. Consumers really only appreciate only a certain amount of raw processing power then the rest enters the law of diminishing returns. It's hard to defend needing four cores when there isn't many apps that are mufti threaded.

Topic.Title: Samsung S4 is further proof that that A15 is a power hog

Message.Msg: Still no real good explanation why a smart phone needs a quadcore processor with a baby core. The Tegra 3 didn't do such a wonderful job on economizing the power. I suspect some consumers will leave certain apps running in the background that will keep all four cores running and draining the phone's power. They will complain about short battery life. ---- To be honest there is very little point in having a quadcore processor in a phone fullstop. Very few apps would use that many threads - except benchmarks:) The baby core (in the Tegra 3/4) as you put it, is a core optimized for low power (in it's layout) but it is the same design as the full power core (A9 in Tegra 3 and A15 in the Tegra 4). Basically, when the SoC is doing very little, this baby core runs thus saving power. In the Exynos 5 Octa, a different approach is taken where 1 quad cluster is one processor type (A7) and the other cluster (A15) is a different type. The idea is similar, you use the A7 cluster when doing very little, then power up the A15's when doing heavy work. As the A7 is very small and uses less power than even the A9, so on paper at least you can save a lot of power.

Topic.Title: Samsung S4 is further proof that that A15 is a power hog

Topic.Title: Wally and Ashraf, please come lecture us on the ARM Bubble again

Message.Msg: getanid61, You're right; it's not all about the fabs. I have to head out now, but I'd be happy to discuss with you further the headwinds that I see for ARM. Fabs are part of the equation, but not really the deal-breaker. My "main" points are: - As Qualcomm/Nvidia take market share, that's less potential Mali royalties for ARM - Imagination Technologies is not sitting still and will likely be a competitor to ARM and will serve, if anything, to keep ARM's royalty rates in check - Intel gaining market share is also a problem as Intel designs its own cores as well as graphics. Bay Trail uses Intel graphics, and I wouldn't be surprised if Merrifield (22nm phone SoC) did too. - Smartphone market itself is showing signs of slowing growth, and that's where ARM makes the big bucks - ARM in servers is not likely to gain traction; AMD was compatible with INTC and even it could not gain any meaningful market share long term And then of course, there's valuation. At $15-$20, I would be a buyer of ARMH in expectation of steady dividend growth, but at $42, it's just hyped up beyond all reasonable expectations.

Topic.Title: Samsung S4 is further proof that that A15 is a power hog

Message.Msg: Thanks for the clarification on that Blue. I did watch the news videos this morning and there a few neat features, not really certain what the quad core brings to the party. This looks like the defacto Android phone to get for the next year as long as the battery life is decent. I'm still of the opinion that the processor improvements are significant on paper and in benchmarks but for the real world other OS features are more important. The tilt screen to scroll feature may become the next big thing for all smart phones in the next couple of years. Still, it's not that significant of a feature. A 13MP camera on a smartpone? I can speak to that, it's starting to get into a range where the optics will start to matter especially in low light situations. I never say "you don't need all those megapixels" because it's just space on a microsd card or hard drive. More is always better.

Message.Title: TSMC looks weak
Message.Msg: Apple to follow ALTR - no way Apple is going to gamble in particular after ALTR announcement. They already need to concern themself with 450mm In other words, while Samsung may go on supplying A6 processors made using 32-nm/28-nm CMOS to Apple for some time, TSMC looks set to be the incumbent at 20-nm but it may have been made clear to the foundry that Apple is already working with Intel aiming at the 14-nm and 10-nm FinFET as a potential alternative to TSMC's 16-nm FinFET roadmap. There are major hurdles to overcome in regards to ltho - issues like overlay. Not just the fins Just read what ASML has to say...

Signal With 71% Accuracy Says This Tech Icon is a Long-Term 'Buy' Many traders try to make decisions using short-term charts, some looking at charts using bars that update every minute or less. These time frames can be useful but individual traders should normally use longer-term charts. Wall Street powerhouses are competing against high-frequency trading firms for the intraday profits that are available and individual traders probably can't match their advantages. Daily charts could be more useful for individuals, but weekly and monthly charts should also be considered. Message.Title: DUAL FORM-FACTOR, DUAL OS
Message.Msg: Intel has announced that with patch for Android 4.2.2, you'll be able to dual boot Android with systems running Windows 8! Imagine getting a hybrid PC like a Lenovo Yoga or a Surface Pro that can also run Android and all Android apps!

Message.Title: PCs will be making a come back this year
Message.Msg: Look at what Intel has set up: - Haswell launch in June - Quad-core Atom around September - Web TV service and set-top box around September (my guess) - Dual boot option for Android and Windows 8 - LTE availability for in first half of this year When you add it all together you have one compelling case to get a new Hybrid PC. With the Hybrid PC you get the following: - Use both as a PC and a tablet - 10 hours of battery life - ability to run Windows 8 apps and games which you cannot do with RT - ability to dual boot and run Android and enjoy all android apps and games - will support WiDi and so allows you to stream videos on your TV if you have the set-top box - can watch live TV if you sign up with Intel's TV service - will support LTE when you need data connection on the go

Message.Title: With a new Atom chip, Intel’s smartphone BFF is ZTE
Message.Msg: After years of trying to crack the mobile market there are still relatively few smartphones with the “Intel Inside” branding. Last year was a bit of a breakthrough, however, as Intel silicon powered the Motorola Razr i handset. Yet few other handset makers have followed suit, leaving Intel with few places to put a mobile foothold. The situation could be changing. On Tuesday, Chinese handset maker ZTE announced a strategic collaboration with Intel on the chipmaker’s latest Atom processor. The Intel Atom Z2580, announced at last month’s Mobile World Congress event, is the focus of the strategy. More important is the fact that ZTE is a fast growing handset maker, currently the No. 4 seller of mobile phones in the world. That data point alone is good news for Intel because it’s not likely the company will get its chips inside devices made by Samsung, Apple, Nokia — although that would be an interesting WinTel mobile play — or many of the other household name mobile device makers. Even better for Intel is ZTE’s base of China: The handset maker’s home country is expected to see big growth in smartphone sales thanks to its large population, improving mobile broadband networks and current lack of smartphone penetration compared to the U.S. and Europe. As a result, depending on how many smartphones come from this agreement, Intel has a key hardware partner in an important mobile market. From gigaoam

Message.Title: Intel and Google are teaming up to circumvent Windows
Message.Msg: Microsoft really p*ssed Intel off my partnering with arm. Now it's pay back time! Three significant piece of news recently: 1) Intel has announced that with Android 4.2.2 you will be able to dual-boot it with systems running Windows 8 2) Google introduced their own branded Chromebook PC (the Pixel) running a Core i5 processor 3) Andy Rubin stepped down as Android head, to be replaced by current head of Chrome OS First, by making Android available on Windows machines, what is the point of using Windows 8 apps on the Metro UI? Developers will probably ask the same question. Second, with the Pixel, you have to ask yourself why you would need a Core i5 to run such a simple OS such as Chrome. The Pixel is surely meant to run Windows 8 as well. We will soon see a dual boot option or some sort of software that will allow the Chrome OS to run on top of Windows 8. Third, with Any Rubin stepping down, it really signals Chrome OS will be merging with Android. There you have it. Google gets into PCs and slowly build out the web/office tools that will slowly be embrace by corporations and consumers alike.

Topic.Title: Intel and Google are teaming up to circumvent Windows

Message.Msg: By the way, with Intel helping Google get into the PCs, don't you think Google will return the favor and help Intel get into phones (even though Intel doesn't really need it). Expect the much anticipated Google X Phone to carry Intel inside.

Message.Title: Crazy Big DELL 18 inch Windows Tablet
Message.Msg: Dell Reveals Crazy Big 18-inch Windows 8 Tablet/AIO 2:00 PM - March 15, 2013 by Kevin Parrish - source: Dell Is it a super-huge tablet, a super-slim AIO PC, or a cool hybrid? Ok, so maybe it's not a tablet but rather a super-thin AIO PC called the Dell XPS 18. Slated to launch here in the United States on April 16 starting at USD 899.99, it will sport an 18.4-inch capacitive touch Full HD display -- nearly twice that of Apple's iPad -- but have an overall weight of 4.85 pounds. That said, should it be characterized as a super-huge tablet or as a super-light AIO? You be the judge. "It features much of the power you would expect from an AIO while still being surprisingly portable, so you can use it in many different rooms in the house," said Dell chief blogger Lionel Menchaca. "It works well as a streaming media device in the living room, viewing recipes or cooking videos in the kitchen, or as a homework machine in the kids' room." While the specs aren't available online, the device will be sold with a Bluetooth mouse and keyboard, with custom flip-out feet to convert the device from a tablet to a desktop. The "starting" model will reportedly include a dual-core Pentium ULV processor and a 320 GB HDD. Higher-end models are said to include a third-generation Intel Core i7 CPU, 8 GB of RAM and a 512 GB SSD. The battery will offer around five hours of life on a single charge. "It features an aluminum back with soft grip for traction and comfort," Menchaca said. "Overall craftsmanship and flexibility were two key focuses for our design team. You can use it in a number of ways: on an adjustable powered stand so it can be used with a wireless keyboard and mouse, on a desk or surface with flip-out feet so it can be set to a comfortable viewing angle, totally flat for collaborating or browsing, or even like a newspaper for reading."

Message.Title: Intel and Qualcom to speak
Message.Msg: Intel, Qualcomm will speak on mobile chip development Mike Rogoway, The Oregonian By Mike Rogoway, The Oregonian on March 15, 2013 at 11:55 AM Few companies illustrate the impact of the mobile computing revolution better than Qualcomm and Intel. Qualcomm has enjoyed a surge of business as electronics demand shifts from the PC to mobile devices, with wireless capabilities tightly integrated with microprocessors. Sales leaped nearly 30 percent last year despite an overall poor year for the chip industry. With a market capitalization topping $110 billion, and its stock near its highest point since the XXXXX era, Qualcomm surpassed Intel last year as the world's most valuable semiconductor company. Intel's sales are more than double Qualcomm's, but those revenues -- and its share price -- are stagnant. Reliant on the slumbering PC industry, Intel has been unable to gain traction in the mobile market. Another big difference: Intel makes its own chips, and bears the cost of all its technology upgrades. Qualcomm contracts that work out. Over time, Intel's manufacturing prowess may give it an advantage -- but that's a long game. The contrasting visions will be on stark display May 1 at a breakfast forum organized by SEMI, a trade group of chip industry suppliers. The event pairs Qualcomm director of business development Samir Kumar with Rohit Vidwans, director of products for Atom -- Intel's mobile chip. The May 1 event, at Intel's Ronler Acres campus in Hillsboro, begins at 8 a.m. Advance tickets are $55 for SEMI members, or $75 for nonmembers. (Prices go up $20 after April 17.)

Topic.Title: PCs will be making a come back this year

Message.Msg: I take it you don't agree that PCs will make a comeback this year? All I can say is, there's big difference between laptops from last year and hybrid laptops from this year. This year you will be seeing hybrids that are thinner, lighter and have 10 hours battery life. Look up 'North cape' for what a Haswell hybrid will look like. When the new quad-core Atom (bay trail) comes out, you will see hybrids that are thinner and lighter than the HP Envy 2 or Samsung Ativ Smart PC and have much much more power. I expect hybrids to start cannibalizing tablets since people like the idea of having a tablet and PC in one device.
